identificationModule.briefTitle: Virtual Reality as a Self-Efficacy Intervention
identificationModule.officialTitle: Improving Self-Efficacy of Hospitalized Children With Virtual Reality Education: A Pragmatic, Crossover Trial

descriptionModule.briefSummary: The goal is to explore the use of Virtual Reality (VR) as an intervention to increase self-efficacy in a healthcare setting. The investigators would like to determine if an educational VR intervention in the course of healthcare could increase pediatric patient self-efficacy compared to standard of care (i.e no VR).
descriptionModule.detailedDescription:
While virtual reality has gained momentum as a therapeutic supplement to distract from pain perception and to reduce anxiety, it has received less attention as an intervention to promote more holistic psychological self-efficacy in the course of in-patient care. Child and adolescent self-reported measures of self-efficacy have also been looked over in favor of parent or practitioner measures of a child's self-efficacy.

To evaluate the effectiveness of virtual reality on child and adolescent self-efficacy while undergoing hospital care, the investigators will determine the effect of virtual reality to 1) increase pediatric patient self-efficacy compared to standard of care using educational virtual reality, 2) establish a comprehensive profile of short-term psychological well-being in school-aged children and adolescents following admission to a hospital. Participants will serve as their own control to either receive intervention on the first day or second day of the in-patient care and no intervention will be given on the other day.

armGroups.label: Virtual Reality then Standard of Care
armGroups.description: Participants will be randomized to receive the virtual reality intervention on the first day and receive standard of care on the second day of in-patient care.

armGroups.label: Standard of Care then Virtual Reality
armGroups.description: Participants will be randomized to receive the standard of care on the first day and receive virtual reality intervention on the second day of in-patient care.

interventions.name: Virtual Reality
interventions.description: During in-patient care participants will be randomized to receive or not receive the educational virtual reality intervention on the first day. After two days, participants will receive a total of 10 minutes interventional in the morning (between 8am to 12pm) every day until their in-patient care concludes.

Virtual Reality then Standard of Care

interventions.name: Standard of Care
interventions.description: For case control, participants will service as their self control and be randomized to receive no virtual reality intervention on either the first day or the second day of in-patient care.

primaryOutcomes.description: Measured with six items from the modified New General Self-Efficacy Scale. The educational self efficacy is scored on scale ranging from 1 (strongly disagree) to 5 (strongly agree)

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Change in current mental well being as measured by the modified WHO (Five) Well-Being Index
secondaryOutcomes.description: The modified WHO (Five) Well-Being Index is a participant-reported outcome measure that assesses current mental well being. Questionnaire contains 5 questions . Scores range from 0 to 5, with higher scores indicating the corresponding feeling exists all the time.

Measured with six items from the modified Intrinsic Motivation Inventory (IMI) - Interest/Enjoyment Subscale. The perceived interest/enjoyment is scored on scale ranging from 1 (Not at all true) to 7 (very true)
Measured with five items from the modified Rosenberg Self-Esteem Scale (child). The self-esteem is scored on scale ranging from 1 (very true) to 4 (Definitely not true)
Measured with five items from the modified Rosenberg Self-Esteem Scale (Adolescent). The self-esteem is scored on scale ranging from 1 (Strongly agree) to 4 (Strongly disagree)

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Change in the caregiver perception of the educational experience of the patient
secondaryOutcomes.description: Measured with seven items from a modified Educational Experience Parental Survey Scale. The caregiver perception of the educational experience of the patient is scored on scale ranging from 1 (strongly disagree) to 7 (strongly agree)

otherOutcomes.measure: Change in the Positive and Negative Affect feeling and emotion for Children
otherOutcomes.description: Measured with ten items from the Positive and Negative Affect Schedule for Children (PANAS-C). The positive affect (PA) and negative affect (NA) feelings and emotions are scored on scale ranging from 1 (Very slightly or not at all) to 5 (Extremely)

eligibilityModule.eligibilityCriteria:
Inclusion Criteria:

* Patients' age range from 5 to 25 at LPCH/SHC facilities

Exclusion Criteria:

* Participants who do not consent
* Have a history of seizure disorder
* Currently have nausea
* Have motion sickness
* Are clinically unstable
* Currently using corrective glasses (not compatible with VR headset)
* Currently pregnant
